meanings.definition: Consign or dismiss to an inferior rank or position.
meanings.sent1: The coach decided to relegate the young player to the bench for the next game.
meanings.sent2: In the company, they often relegate new employees to less challenging tasks at first.
meanings.sent3: When the cat refused to catch the mouse, the mouse jokingly threatened to relegate the cat to mouse duty.
meanings.sent4: The old typewriter was relegated to a corner of the attic, gathering dust and memories.
meanings.sent5: The teacher's harsh words seemed to relegate the student to a state of perpetual embarrassment.

meanings.definition: Transfer to a less important position.
meanings.sent1: The manager had to relegate some of the staff to different departments due to budget cuts.
meanings.sent2: After the promotion, she was reluctant to relegate her previous responsibilities to someone else.
meanings.sent3: The superhero accidentally used his powers to relegate his cape to the laundry pile.
meanings.sent4: The fading sunlight seemed to relegate the once vibrant flowers to shadows in the garden.
meanings.sent5: The storm's strong winds threatened to relegate the fragile tent to a crumpled mess.

meanings.definition: Assign an inferior rank or position to.
meanings.sent1: The king would often relegate those who displeased him to the dungeons.
meanings.sent2: She didn't want to relegate her loyal assistant to a lower role, but the decision had to be made.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous elf tried to relegate the grumpy gnome to the role of chief cookie taster.
meanings.sent4: The artist's new masterpiece seemed to relegate all previous works to mere sketches in comparison.
meanings.sent5: The powerful storm threatened to relegate the sturdy tree to a pile of splintered branches.
